title: Tax debt split in divorce? Is it fraud?
question: My wife told me she filed jointly online taxes for 10 years. Instead she filed only for herself and claimed head of household, lying to me. Now filing for divorce, I have gone back and filed old taxes as married separately. Is my tax debt from those years during our marriage (plus penalties) half hers in the divorce?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce settlement agreements,Filing for divorce,Divorce petitions and complaints,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,State, local, and municipal law,Tax law
answers:
Regardless of whether your wife's actions were fraudulent, your duty to file is non-delegable. You are held responsible by the Service. If returns were not filed married filing jointly, then innocent spouse relief may not be available unless equity demands. You may have reasonable cause to request abatement of penalties. Also, allocation and/or payment of taxes may be a negotiating point for your divorce settlement. You should meet with a tax advisor to discuss.

Tax debts in general belong to the taxpayer who signs the return. In the case of married filing joint taxpayers, both husband and wife are liable on the tax debt even if all the "innocent" taxpayer does is sign.

Debts in divorce are a different matter and depending on the state, debts of one individual may be deemed to be marital debt in which case a portion of the debt will be allocated to the spouse.

What can also happen depending on the facts and circumstances is that the "innocent" spouse can apply for innocent spouse relief from the IRS with respect to the years at issue. The IRS in turn may go after the other spouse for fraud and accuracy-related penalties. Those debts of the non-innocent spouse may stay with that spouse in divorce pursuant to state law. Divorce courts generally will allocate the tax debt pursuant to the principles of equity if presented with facts.
